title: Incas (Tawantinsuyu)
common: In addition to using the name America, we will also refer to the continent as Abya Yala, a term used by the indigenous peoples of the continent (Porto-Gonçalves, Carlos Walter, , pp. 39-43).

The Inca genealogy, in some publications, have twelve generations (Rowe, J. H., 1945, pp. 267 ; Niles, Susan A., 1988, pp. 56), but there is necessity to study them deeper. The Juan Betanzos chronicle has little information about the first 7 generations (Betanzos, Juan, 2010, pp. 1 - 18), while the Poma de Ayala chronicle (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615) is classified as "lleno de medias verdades, de fantasías, y tal vez de sueños" [a lot of partial truths, fantasies, and possibly dreams] (Gebran, Philomena, 2018, pp. 2 - 4), or "whortless" (Rowe, J. H., 1945, pp. 274) due issues like mix of worldview:

  • The first chief, Mango Capac, is a descendant of the Sun, and he had a marriage with his mother (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 80 - 81, 87, 121 ; Gebran, Philomena, 2018, pp. 4). Juan Betanzos' description about this chief also have mythological concepts (Betanzos, Juan, 2010, pp. 13 - 16)
  • Sinchi Roca became the ruler, and years later, his wife, the second "Coya", gave birth to Jesus Christ. Jesus and his apostle moved around the world, he was crucified, he died, he was buried, and he resurrected going to heaven (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 87 - 89, 123 ; Gebran, Philomena, 2018, pp. 6 - 7). On the other hand, Juan Betanzos describes as a unique son, he had a marriage with a woman from another kingdom, and he had a son (Betanzos, Juan, 2010, pp. 17).
  • The heir, Lloquí Yupanqui, have to highlight the fact he used a ring from the three magi kings, and he also had marriage with a sister. He passed away when he was one hundred third years old (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 91 - 97, 125 ; Gebran, Philomena, 2018, pp. 7). Juan Betanzos also adds myths to his life, putting him in the same level of Merlin (Betanzos, Juan, 2010, pp. 17).
  • Mayta Capac, son of the previous. He passed away when he was also more than one hundred years old (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 97 - 99 ; Gebran, Philomena, 2018, pp. 7). Juan Betanzos reports little about him (Betanzos, Juan, 2010, pp. 18).

The four first generations have impossible events describing them, it is possible this was the reason Susan A. Niles classify them as mythological (Niles, Susan A., 1988, pp. 56), while the next three generations are classified as unknown, because we do not have enough data to confirm they existed:
  • Capac Yupanqui, had also a marriage with his sister, Chimbo Mama Caua, that passed away early, having issues in her heart. After the first sister death, he had a marriage with another sister, Mama Micay. In addition to children names, nothing significant was added by Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 99 - 103, 127 - 129 ; Gebran, Philomena, 2018, pp. 7). He is not cited by Juan Betanzos.
  • Inca Roca succeeded his father, and he has a shorter description, where appear his [supposed] descendant that became ruler, it is also said he passed away when he was one hundred fifty years olds (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 103 ; Gebran, Philomena, 2018, pp. 7 - 8). Juan Betanzos also reports little about him (Betanzos, Juan, 2010, pp. 18).
  • Yahuar Huacac does not have relevant information either. He also lived more than one hundred years. He would be father of the first chief considered real in the papers used on this page (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 103 - 105 ; Gebran, Philomena, 2018, pp. 8). Juan Betanzos reports little about him (Betanzos, Juan, 2010, pp. 18).

The Inca, Tawantinsuyu, empire was the biggest empire of America (Abya Ayla) in the beginning of 16th century (Raffino, Rodolfo & Stehberg, Rubén, 1999, pp. 168 - 169). This expansion trajectory began with Cusi Yupanki, son of Viracocha, that became chief, renaming himself to Pachacuti Inca Yupanki (Lumbreras, Luis G., 1967, pp. 427 - 428 ; Rowe, J. H., 1945, pp. 267, 269 - 270 ; Niles, Susan A., 1988, pp. 56). It is from their governments that periods, as proposed Cabello become reliable. With this, the Inca Empire grew up during only 94 years (Rowe, J. H., 1945, pp. 277, 281). The wife citation on this page is done with caution, due to the source that informs them.

families.name: Família de Viracocha
history: Viracocha is the first chief that was possible to prove the existence, his descendants built one of the biggest empires of America (Abya Ayla).

people.name: Viracocha
history: According to Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala, he is a legitimate son of Yaur Uacac Inga and the seventh Coya, Mama Machi Coya. He had a marriage with Mama Yunto Cayan Coya, and he lived to be one hundred andd twenty-four years old (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 105, 135 ; Gebran, Philomena, 2018, pp. 8).

He was Cusco chief, during this ruler time, he organized the conquered districts (Rowe, J. H., 1945, pp. 269 - 270). He ruled until the year of 1438 (Rowe, J. H., 1945, pp. 269 - 270 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 107), when he showed some weakness leaving Cusco and giving the power to his son and commanders (Lumbreras, Luis G., 1967, pp. 427).

The first chapters of Juan Betanzos chronicle are dedicated to the creator that has the same name as this chief. He is also the first chief to have facts that can be confirmed, and extensive description in the chronicle (Betanzos, Juan, 2010, pp. 1 - 8, 18 - 26).

marriages.name: Mama Yunto Cayan Coya
history: According to Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala (Gebran, Philomena, 2018, pp. 8 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 107, 135).

children.name: Pachacuti Inca Yupanki, Cusi Yupanki
history: According to different researchers and Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala (Lumbreras, Luis G., 1967, pp. 427 ; Niles, Susan A., 1988, pp. 56 ; Rowe, J. H., 1945, pp. 267, 270 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 107).

children.name: Urcon Inca
history: According to John H. Rowe and Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala (Rowe, J. H., 1945, pp. 270 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 107).

children.name: Mama Anauarque
history: According to Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala (Rowe, J. H., 1945, pp. 270 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 107).

people.name: Urcon Inca
history: According to John H. Rowe, he was the preferred son to succeed his father (Rowe, J. H., 1945, pp. 270). Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayla, on the other hand, cites Pachacuti as the first son (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 107). We have the conclusion that John H. Rowe had access to documentation that this project did not study yet.

people.name: Mama Anauarque
history: Her marriage is cited by Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayla, Phlomena Gebran and Roberto Moras (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 107 - 109, 137 ; Gebran, Philomena, 2018, pp. 8 ; Moras, Roberto, 2023, Youtube), but Tom Zuidema cites her as a "mítica" [mithlogica] person (Zuidema, Tom, 2008, pp. 49).
Her descendants are listed in her husband, and also brother, section.

marriages.name: Pachacuti Inca Yupanki, Cusi Yupanki
history: According to different researchers and Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala (Gebran, Philomena, 2018, pp. 8 ; Zuidema, Tom, 2008, pp. 49 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 109, 137).

people.name: Pachacuti Inca Yupanki, Cusi Yupanki
history: Cabello Balboa does an arbitrary affirmation, that the victory of Pachacuti against his enemies, the Chancas, happened between years 1430 and 1440 (Lumbreras, Luis G., 1967, pp. 428).

He had a marriage with his sister, according to different researchers and Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala (Gebran, Philomena, 2018, pp. 8 ; Zuidema, Tom, 2008, pp. 49 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 107). He proceeds with the kingdom expansion until the year of 1471 (Rowe, J. H., 1945, pp. 270, 271 ; Lumbreras, Luis G., 1967, pp. 428 ; Moras, Roberto, 2023, Youtube), the year that he probably passed away.
Figura 1: Photo of Pachacuti statue in Cusco city (Sitios del Patrimonio Mundial del Perú). Photo taken on 18 August, 2017 during visit to city.

Here we present only a short summary about his life, but he was really important to Inca Empire, and Juan Betanzos used the majority of his chronicle (Betanzos, Juan, 2010, pp. 26 - 135) to talk about him, so we suggest studying and watch the cited sources.

children.name: Tupak Inca Yupanki
history: According to disticnt researches and Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala (Lumbreras, Luis G., 1967, pp. 428 ; Niles, Susan A., 1988, pp. 56 ; Rowe, J. H., 1945, pp. 267, 270 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 109).

people.name: Tupak Inca Yupanki
history: A well known man of war (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 111) that continued the empire expansion, like his father (Raffino, Rodolfo & Stehberg, Rubén, 1999, pp. 168 ; Rowe, J. H., 1945, pp. 271 - 272 ; Lumbreras, Luis G., 1967, pp. 428).
He ruled until the year of 1493 (Niles, Susan A., 1988, pp. 56) and he had a marriage with (Gebran, Philomena, 2018, pp. 8 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 111, 139).

marriages.name: Ocllo Coya
history: According to Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala (Gebran, Philomena, 2018, pp. 8 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 111, 139).

children.name: Huyna Capac
history: According to different researches (Lumbreras, Luis G., 1967, pp. 428 ; Niles, Susan A., 1988, pp. 56 ; Rowe, J. H., 1945, pp. 267, 270).

people.name: Huayna Capac, Guayanacaba
history: A person with large description in Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala's chronicle, with an important fact, his wife has the same name as his mother (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 111 - 114). In his government, the empire continued the expansion, probably reaching the current country of Argentina (Raffino, Rodolfo & Stehberg, Rubén, 1999, pp. 168 ; Rowe, J. H., 1945, pp. 272 ; Lumbreras, Luis G., 1967, pp. 428).

When had a trip with Pizarro in the first years of the colonization, Pedro Sánchez de Hoz brought important information about this chief (De Hoz, Pedro S., 1534, pp. 125 - 126, 135 - 138, 142 - 143), despite he was not more the ruler. When he describes the city of Cusco, he informs about the city walls "Los Españoles que la ven dicen, que ni el puente de Segovia, ni otro de los edificios hicieron Hercules ni los Romanos, no son cosas tan dignas de verse como esto." [The Spanish people that can see it speaks, that neither the Segovia bridge, nor another building made by Hercules, and Roman, are not so worthy like these] (De Hoz, Pedro S., 1534, pp. 127).
The end of his government is uncertain, and it is estimated between 1525 and 1529 (Niles, Susan A., 1988, pp. 56 ; De Hoz, Pedro S., 1534, pp. 142 ; Lumbreras, Luis G., 1967, pp. 427 - 428).

marriages.name: Mama Ocllo
history: According to Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala and Glossary of Pedro Sánchez de Hoz chronicle (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 114 ; De Hoz, Pedro S., 1534, pp. 142).

marriages.name: Paccha
history: According to Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala and Glossary of Pedro Sánchez de Hoz chronicle (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 114 ; De Hoz, Pedro S., 1534, pp. 140).

children.name: Huascar
history: According to Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala and Glossary of Pedro Sánchez de Hoz chronicle (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 114 ; De Hoz, Pedro S., 1534, pp. 142).

children.name: Atauallpa
history: According of Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala and Glossary of Pedro Sánchez de Hoz chronicle (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 114 ; De Hoz, Pedro S., 1534, pp. 140) .

people.name: Huascar
history: After three large periods of leadership among chiefs, this stayed only seven years (Niles, Susan A., 1988, pp. 56) in a double government with Atauallpa, during a civil war period (Lumbreras, Luis G., 1967, pp. 428 - 429). He passed away without heir (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 116).

marriages.name: Chuquillanto Coya
history: According to Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala (Gebran, Philomena, 2018, pp. 8 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, 1615, pp. 116).

people.name: Atauallpa
history: The last Inca chief. He became ruler when he was together to his father in Quito. After his brother passed away, he was arrested and killed by Spanish people around the year 1532 (Lumbreras, Luis G., 1967, pp. 428 - 429). The fall of Atauallpa in Cajamarca, is also known as "Celada de Cajamarca" [Cajamarca snare] (Academia Play, 2019, 01:25).
